Overall, a different style of Pumpkin Ale but the Rum Barrel Aging just overpowers the smell/taste and leaves your mouth very boozy.

12 oz bottle. 2013 vintage. Pours golden and clear. Huge aroma of rum, sweet, and booze. Very sweet and boozy. A but of vanilla, cinnamon, and pumpkin on the back end. Very, Very rum. Tons of rum. So much rum. Even rummier than I thought anything possibly could be.

22, capped and foiled. Thanks D! Pours a murky dark brown with a light creamy tan head. Definite molasses, pumpkin pie, vanilla, and oak on the nose, along with some caramel and huge wafts of vodka. Creamy medium body with soft carb. Sweet and sticky mid palate, lots of molasses and pumpkin pie knocking around. Somewhat glyceral feel. Long sticky sweet hot finish.

Brewvival 2011, on tap. Clear copper amber small white
Sweet spice rum and carmel aoma
Sweet pumpkin spice caramel and fruit flavor
Med full bod mod low carb

UPDATED: SEP 30, 2013 Whoa! Unlike any other pumpkin beer Ive had to date. Outrageous flavor that packs a punch. Loving everything about this beer, except the price and wait in line on release day... Great Job Avery! ---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
12oz bottle from 2012. Pours a dark orange amber with a small tan head. Big pumpkin and rum aroma. Great spice tase with pumpkin and wood taste. Great beer.

2012 Bottle. Pours clear copper with no head, tons of bubbles, and some sediment in the glass. The aroma has big nutmeg, cinnamon, pumpkin puree, oak, and a bit of vanilla. The taste has a kick of pumpkin pie followed by what can only be called pure rum sweetness. Very good.

Refrigerated 12 oz. brown bottle poured into a snifter. Pours tranlucent orange with no head, no lacing, and carbonation. Aroma is pumpkin and medium body. Taste is pumpkin, rum, oak, and a hint of alcohol. Not easy to drink, but if you sip it, it is pretty good.  The alcohol is well covered for 18%.
Bottle. This stuff is like fermented pumpkin hooch. Good god is it boozy. Very thick, syrupy and sweet. This bottle was split 8 ways and my 1.5oz was more than enough. Good, but never again.

36cl, Batch 2, at 18.1%Vol, new exclusive American brew Anno 2010, with pumpkins, thx to kraddel!, very complex brew, alcoholic/sweet and slightly spicy/woody, heavy, yet balanced, clear, nearly no head, very good and original brew!, WOW!

2012 vintage . 
pours copper, no foam. smell is boozy , pumpkin, soft carbo . boozyness, ruùm indeed ! pumpkin-sweetness , very sweet actualy. boozyness is just borderline.. a hint more and it would be too much...

This bottle was from Strykzone.  Pours clear dark copper/\ color with a beige head. Nose of pumpkin, spices, wood, and RUM.  Lot so rum  Body full with alcohol showing  Flavor is rum and spice.  Alcoholic finish. VERY tasty.

Batch 002. Pours a nice dark amber with absolutely zero carbonation. Aromas are pumpkin, caramel, and very active rum and wood scents. Flavors are exactly like the nose predicts, though there are some more nuanced spices mixed in and the alcohol flavors are tremendously good. The palate is super heavy and coats the tongue with a near liquor level of sticky, but even a little carbonation would help this out. Overall, this is a stellar beer, definitely the best pumpkin beer I have tasted, but a little too heavy and big to enjoy all the time; where it really wins is in the bottle size, 12 oz. is perfect for a beer this big.

This is a Big Beer. A smooth sipping pumpkin ale with all the requisite flavors, in abundance, and recommended.

Sweet, caramelly, boozy, pumpkiny, cinnamony. Flavorful and pretty delicious.
A beer that I wasnt expecting to be that great but it is pretty good. Boozy and thick as hell but a pleasnt interplay of rum and pumpkin.
Holy shit this is sweet and boozy.  These kinds of beers really are lost on me.  So sweet and thick and full of spice and booze.  Like an odd holiday liquor or something.
Ok, very sweet and strong, cloying sweet, boozy as shit. I prefer sessionable beers

2011. I don't really like the aroma: supercharged malts with mediocre pumpkin spices alongside.

Taste is a different story altogether. Rum spices up front, Fall spices + aged booze sweetness in the middle, finishes with an oaky kick and plenty of boozy warmth.

Highly refined. Damn, this stuff is delicious.

3rd March 201215.9% version. Cloudy brown beer, tidy pale tan head. Silky palate with a little fine carbonation. Sweet malt with some port wine flavours. A little sweet pumpkin and spice - well integrated. Touch of dark rum and a trace of vanilla wood. Finishes semi dry with mild warmth. Pretty well integrated. Tasty and a bit different!

Pours from the bottle a very nice copper color that certainly implies pumpkin, with a small and insignificant head.  The aroma is really big.  Theres a lot of pumpkin and spice, and a hell of a lot of alcohol in the nose.  The taste is like a very, very strong Belgian ale with some pumpkin and rum tones and lots of heat.  The alcohol in this thing isnt hidden at all, its right up front.  Not bad, but might be better with some age on it.

12oz bottle, thanks to adnielsen. My bottle is batch #2. bottled 9/17/12. ABV labeled 18.1%. Hazy (pretty much opaque) dark orange / red color. No head, no lace. Rum and pumpkin gourd nose. Spicy flavor, big satisfying pumpkin, awesome amount of rum - a lot of rum barrel wood. But still a massive amount of gourdy pumpkin in this, very satisfying. Alcohol in this is detectable, but not 18% detectable. Seems more drinkable than DFHs WWS and 120m, but still has a sort of bite in the finish. Otherwise, hint of sweetness, more spiciness. Bigger body, but its very dry. Carbonation is lighter but noticable. Very long, delicious pumpkin / rum barrel wood finish. Awesome, fascinating, intensely tasty stuff. Great to sip and savor.

Bottle thanks to fatknitty.  Pours a golden-red color with a very small off-white head.  Aroma is pumpkin, pumpkin pie spice, caramel, butterscotch, vanilla, wood, rum, alcohol.  Taste is extremely sweet but enjoyable, with some nice spice.  Finish is sweet, with lots of oak and spice, alcohol as well but not a lot for 18%.  Full bodied, soft carbonation.  Nice sipper.

Bottle thanks to Perrin515. Pours amber orange. Quick dissipating off-white head. Nose and taste of pumpkin puree, rum barrel, oak, nutmeg, cinnamon and all spice. Lots of alcohol in the finish. A bit hot like a pumpkin liquor. Decent as a sipper, but I couldnt even finish half the bottle. Too sweet and boozy. Off balanced.  Medium body.

Oh. My. Gosh! Such a balance of sweet, spice, and pumpkin. Sharpie marker lingers after a decadent, velvety pumpkin pie. And the rum! It seems so simple, so obvious but Avery has done it! This rivals some of my favorites and its a pumpkin!!!

Pumpkin, booze, malt aroma.  Pours a golden caramel color with almost no head.  Dark fruit, caramel, pumpkin.  Drinks like a nice smooth liqueur with a light clean finish.  This was an incredible beer.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle from Total Wine Sterling.  It pours a hazy deep red color with a very short lived tan head.  Lots of effervescent action but no head.  The nose has nice oak and dark rum notes, a little roasted pumpkin, and pumpkin spice.  The flavor is sweet with notes of pumpkin, pumpkin spice, wood, and spiced rum.  The alcohol is there the whole way, but at almost 16% thats to be expected.  Lasting dark caramel malt and earthy pumpkin finish.  A great beer for dessert in lieu of a slice of pumpkin pie.

Bottle for wchesser, thanks Will!!  Aroma has great notes of pumpkin, autumn spices, ginger bread, cinnamon, nutmeg, wood, molasses, Rum and booze.  Great aroma!  Murky medium brown hue with little head that fully diminished and left no lace.  The most fugly brew Ive had in recent memory.  Flavor is very very sweet and medium bitter.  Palate is very very full bodied and oily soft.  Overall a really good autumn brew.  Very complex, a lot of character in the aroma, great palate, no sign of that huge abv except a little in the aroma.  I do have to say it is one ugly brew, but other than that I absolutely loved it.  But Avery still sucks.

Bottle at Fobab 10. Pours a deep orange brown with an offwhite head. The nose shows pumpkin spice. Earthy and rich, light cinnamon and some noted booze. Vanilla & molasses as well. On tasting, it is a big and rich beer. Moderate sweetness is balanced by a tannin structure, both from the spicing and the oak. Vanilla and sweetness, big booze. Earthy. Clean finish. Really nice stuff and doesnt drink like 18%.

Pours a beautiful brown color. Smells of pumpkin pie. Flavor is the same with a bit of alcohol warmth to finish. Great beer.

In short: A brutal uber-sweet, spicy and boozy atrocity.  Unpalatable.
How: Bottle 12oz, not sure about the age (around 8 months old I think), bottle sent to me by adnielsen, thanks Aaron.
The look: Ugly murky amber-brown body with almost no head.
In long: Nose is intensely sweet dessert, cinnamon bun with glazing, sweet pumpkin pie.  Taste is spicy Christmas candy cane, ice-cream cone (without ice-cream), cinnamon, nutmeg, brown sugars, alcohol heat, pumpkin seeds, pastry, spicy hard candies (like those classic red fish-shaped candies), sweet cough syrup, cheap sweet table syrup, a shot of cheap hard liquor.  And I could probably go on and one, doesnt mean the beer is complex, just that it is very intense and so sweet and also spicy that it can taste many things.  Have I noticed the 15% abv before opening the bottle I think I would have cellared it for a full year.  Body is not even rich despite the abv, just very very sweet and juicy, the texture of a concentrate fruit juice with carbonation.  This is gross, I couldnt finish a singly 12oz bottle.  I know ratebeer scores are mostly a measure of intensity and not quality but Im still very much puzzled as to how a piece of junk like this can get such good marks.  I cant believe the good ratings I see for this awful beer, I swear we could power my office building just using the wind of all the sighing I do at work when reading other people ratings.

The beer is sunburst orange with a thin, off white cap. The aroma yields booze, malt, spices. Good flavor, with rum emerging more so than in the aroma. Sweet, and best in small doses. Alcohol is there, but not a barrier to enjoyment, even in spite of the nearly 16% abv. Overall, very good. I would definitely have this again.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-01-2012

A - Pours a cloudy orange-brown with a finger of frothy off-white head. The head fades down at a normal pace leaving behind some nice lacing.

S - Aroma is a mix of sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, oak, rum, pumpkin, pumpkin pie spices, nutmeg, cinnamon, a bit of dark fruit, and some booze.

T - Starts off with some caramel malts with some brown sugar, pumpkin, nutmeg, and cinnamon. Through the middle, some oak and Rum comes through with some more pumpkin pie spices and a bit of dark fruit. The finish is a mix of brown sugar, Rum, oak, caramel malts, pumpkin, pumpkin pie spices, dark fruit, and some booze.

M - Medium-full bodied with moderate carbonation. Feels smooth with a sweet, warming, and spicy finish.

D - Very drinkable. The almost 16% abv is well hidden and the overall balance is fantastic.

Batch 2, bottled 9/17/12. 12 oz foil topped bottle into a brandy snifter.

A - Pours a rather clear burnt orange/brown color. Some small off white bubbles dissipate quickly leaving behind a very still body. Swirling creates some minute bubbles and leaves behind a thin alcoholic trace.

S - Pumpkin and squash flesh, cinnamon, nutmeg, and some rich malty toffee. The finish is harsh alcohol and some sweet vanilla. The beginning is quite nice and reminiscent of many pumpkin ales, but the alcohol just burns the nose and prevents the aroma from being approachable. I find myself smelling it from a few inches away from the glass rather than stuffing my nose in like most beers. 

T - Starts off with some basic roasted pumpkin flesh flavors along with the standard spices of cinnamon, nutmeg, brown sugar, and all spice. These flavors are then interrupted by a huge wave of alcohol that burns the mouth and throat. Aftertaste is of oak and some brief vanilla. The rum is hardly noticeable. Disappointing and light in the flavor department. Its saving grace is that its not too sweet or cloying.

M - Medium to thin bodied with low carbonation. Drink ability is quite low. Im struggling with the first 6 oz pour.

O - I really wanted to like this one, but alas Im just left perplexed. Sticking a pumpkin ale in a rum barrel sounds like an amazing idea. Somewhere along the line Avery decided to make the beer an 18% abv monster. Big boozy beers rarely bother me, but this one is just a bit too harsh and simple.
Pours orange gold into a snifter. White head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Pumpkin and rum aromas. Hot sweet caramel upfront turning to pumpkin before the hot lasting rum and oak finish.
Poured a viscous medium auburn with virtually no head. Nose of rum and spices. Very heavy across the tongue in a pleasent way. Very warming and a bit boozy in a good way.

Bottle to taster (thanks Bunker). Looks good; a transparent dark orange with off-white lacing. Smells good too; pumpkin and rum. Tastes like it smells with a good rum sinus-cleaning mouthfeel. Nice on the palate too. Tasty!

12oz bottle via trade. Clear golden amber with a small head and big time legs. Aroma of pumpkin pie, cough syrup, fruity esters and alcohol. Flavor is hot alcohol burn, pumpkin pie and sweet sugary malt. Medium body with a long finish. Fresh this one really shows the 18%, almost like a pumpkin liqueur.

Traded bottle from Dakine at home.  Well that makes sense now...18.1 ABV! Huge notes of rum HOWEVER the rum did not overpower the pumpkin and spice. Keep drinking this because although the first taste is a little eye-opening, everything mellows out really well as it warms slightly. This is definitely a sipper. I was pleasantly surprised because often times I think Avery is over-the-top but not this time.

Aroma- figs, dark fruits, rum, spices, orange liqueur, booze
Appearance- hazy sunset orange with a dominate alcohol presence and virtually no head
Taste- booze soaked raisins followed by caramel/rum sweetness, slight pumpkin follows and the shifts over to spices and more booze
Palate- syrupy and just about cloyingly so
Overall-  Too much for me.  I had the 2011 vintage and it was a complete booze bomb.  Rum is not one of my favorite spirits and even in its limited capacity in this brew, it made is sickly sweet and off-balanced.
This is a great pumpkin beer, has bold pumpkin, pie crust, cinnamon and nutmeg scents. Taste is similar, nice creamy pumpkin pie flavors.

2011 bottle. Moderate orange pour with a creamy off-white head.  Aroma of spice, pumpkin, and lots of rum.  Pumpkin spice and pumpkin up front with a healthy dose of rum at the back end.  Warms on the way down.  Definitely a sipping beer.

12 ounce bottle, 2011 vintage, poured a dark orange color, aromas of light pumpkin pie, light spice and huge boozy rumy goodness.  Flavors were pumpkin up front with some all spice, and boozy aftertaste.  This beer warmed me up with every sip I took, nice beer overall.

This poured a darker orange to amber color with a tiny off white head.  Aroma was straight oxidation and rum, not very surpirsed, but thats what it was.  Flavor was oxidized barleywine, very faint pumpkin spice notes and lots of rum.  Big and brash and a bit of a disappointment.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2013 Bottle at home. 2012 Vintage; 18.1%! Pour is murky amber with no head, but greatl long legs. Caramel, brown sugar, spice, light sweet potato, figs, ginger, cinnamon, and raisins in the aroma with a slight alcoholic burn on my nostrils. Nice! The pumpkin aroma really starts to open up. Taste is not too reminiscent of a pumpkin beer, although the sweet yam flavor is there. Really reminds me of a barley wine, caramel, brown sugar, nutmeg, gingerbread, spiced rum, clove, and figs with a light bitter finish and slight alcoholic burn. Not overbearing at all, though. Suprisingly full body with decent carbonation. Really complex beer and much like a spiced English barley wine, although not overly sweet. So complex and super easy-to-drink for such a high ABV. Definitely the best pumpkin beer I have ever had. Really nice stuff.

12oz into a snifter.

cloudy, hazy. Head went away extremely fast. Being 18% doesnt surprise me. Herb and spice completely overtake the nose. The rum barrels add an awesome sweetness and nose. Nutmeg, cinnamon, pumpkin, followed by the run barrel vanilla, carmel notes make this an amazing imperial pumpkin beer. The alcohol is present on the back end. Still very good. Going to keep looking for another bottle.

Poured from a refrigerated 12 ounce bottle graciously send to me from adnielsen. Thanks again! Poured into a miniature snifter. The beer is a darker copper color with a decent head. The aroma is full of barrel notes with caramel, vanilla, leather, and butterscotch. Unfortunately, I think I let this set too long, as no pumpkin whatsoever is really coming through. Taste is sweet and earthy. I cant get over how well Avery is able to cover the ridiculous alcohol content of some of their beers. Nearly 16% abv and I wouldnt have guessed it over 9 if it were handed to me blindly.

Bottle shared by a friend at Septoberfest V: Septoberfest Rises on 9/29/12. Pours clear orange in color with a medium beige head. Nose consisting of rum, cinnamon and malt. Malty and boozy flavor with lots of spice before a boozy finish. Will wake up your palate for sure, but very tasty.

Gold foil wrapped 12 oz. bottle served in a Bells Tulip. Bottled 10/5/2011.

A: Pours an almost brown body with dark orange a small, quick dissolving off white head. It recedes to a very thin collar, but doesnt leave any lace. The body is lively with carbonation though.

S: Smells like a rum soaked pumpkin pie. Crumbly pie crust, pumpkin pulp, cinnamon, allspice, a touch of nutmeg and some sweet rum round this guy out. Very interesting to say the least.

T: The taste takes a complete 180 here. Notes of caramel, burnt sugar, rum soaked dark fruits and some oak all shine together. A sweet spiced rum makes its presence known in the middle and a malty vanilla sweetness thats almost on the verge of be cloying rounds it out. The is a great warming sensation on the finish, but it isnt hot. There is barely any pumpkin to be found.

M: Full bodied with a stick and coating mouthfeel, yet the carbonation is slightly prickly to keep the tongue interested. The taste lingers in the mouth for quite sometime. This is definitely a sipper.

O: This was a very interesting beer. It had old ale and barleywine qualities to it. The pumpkin gets lost in the taste really and I would have like more of the nose to shine through in taste. If it had a touch more pumpkin I would have given this a much higher score. Not bad, very different.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-08-2012
Bottle thanks to phaleslu.  About one year of age.   Notes of big sweet barley wine,  sweet caramel,  sugar,  ozidized.  Too sweet.  Too boozy.  Undrinkable.

Hazy ruby-amber color with a medium frothy light brown head that diminishes steadily. Partial rings of lacing. The aroma consists of ginger, pumpkin and rum. Full-bodied sipper with flavors of pumpkins, charred marshmallow, vanilla and rum. The finish is boozy rum with a lingering baked pumpkin and vanilla aftertaste. Good beer all around.

12 oz. bottle poured into a snifer.  Pours a copper color with a medium to small beige head that is gone in a second.  Nose is rum, caramel, pumpkin, cinnamon, alcohol.  Flavor is huge rum, pumpkin, spice.  Alcohol is well hidden.  Interesting and very tasty.

12oz bottle. Poured a well carbonated caramel color, small fizzy white head. Aroma was cinnamon, some nutmeg, sweet malts, and plenty of booze. Jeez, this one is boozy, hot, and this is a bottle from 2011. To a certain extent I appreciate where they were going with this, but its not really all that enjoyable for me, even only 12 ounces was too much. Scale back the booze, and sure - Ill give it another go.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2015 Cellared this beer for over 9 monthsPours a clear, dark brown body. Head is a 1/4 inch and tan in color. Lacing was average and head retention was good for such a strong beer. Smell is of sweet pumpkin pie puree mixed with nutmeg, cinnamon,  spiced rum and light alcohol. Sweet caramel, candied figs, and Belgian rock sugar round out the aromas. Hops are not present, this beer is all about sweet malt and spiced pumpkin.Taste is of sweet, buttery diacetyls, pumpkin pie, clove and nutmeg. Caramelized brown sugar and Belgian Rock sugar is also there, this beer shares similarities  to a high quality barleywine or quad. Hops are non existent, alcohol is faint but for 16% alcohol, dangerously well hidden. Rum barrel added some sweetness and spice to overall flavor. Mouthfeel is medium bodied, slightly syrupy, pretty typical for the alcohol content. The head could have been fuller, thats my only gripe with the texture of this beer.Overall this beer was amazing. I?ve had it fresh and aging it for almost a year has transformed it into a completely different class. This beer is definitely the gold standard when it comes to Pumpkin/spiced beers, yet its uniquely different from any pumpkin beer I?ve had. Its a shame that there is no more of this beer available and no plans have been made to release it again. One thing is for certain though, if it does get released again, I will be hoarding a case for my collection.

12 oz. bottle via adnielsen.  Pours a dark copper brown color with a medium to large yellowish beige head.  The aroma introduces itself very quickly with spiced rum, sweet caramel malt, wood, fleshy pumpkin with the usual spices, cinnamon, allspice and some alcohol.  The beer is full bodied and syrupy.  Big sweet malt flavor enhanced with rum, wood, pumpkin, cinnamon and allspice.  There is no doubt you are drinking a big beer, but the alcohol mostly serves to warm and doesnt get in the way of the flavors.

(Bottle) Pours dark orange brown. The aroma holds cinnamon, vanilla, nutmeg, rum, brown sugar, wood, pumpkin, peppery alcohol, bread, fudge and toffee. The flavour is medium to heavily sweet, light to medium bitter and light acidic with notes of syrup, alcohol, Christmas spices, pumpkin, rum and dough. The mouthfeel is round, light sticky and numbing with a light carbonation. Pumpkin, alcohol, light rum and dough on the finish. Medium to full bodied.

355 ml bottle courtesy of Marsiblursi. Pours clear amber with a small fizzy offwhite head that quickly dissipates without leaving much trace on the glass. Smell is very sweet with pumpkin, rum, alcohol, cinnamon, nutmeg, graham crackers, toffee, vanilla fudge, butternut squash and wood. Taste is sweet, fruity and spicy with pumpkin, nutmeg, rum, sweet dark bread, cinnamon, lemon grass, allspice, alcohol, wood and vanilla toffee. Mouthfeel is round, sticky sweet, boozy and medium to full bodied. Finish is sweet with pumpkin, rum, cinnamon, nutmeg and sweet dark bread. Nice but to be enjoyed in small glasses.

Bottle at Mumsig Miniprovning, Göteborg. Amber beer with a small offwhite head. Pumpkin aroma, fruity, rum notes, toffee notes.  Pumpkin flavor, spicy, rum, sweetish, nutmeg, faint hop notes, fruity, pepper. Hoppy bitter finish, spicy, pumpkin. Quite nice but on the edge of becoming onedimensional.

Bottle @ MMP. Pours cloudy deepee alber with a minimal ring of off white bubbles. Aroma is sweet rum malty spicy cinnamon cloves raisins fidges. Flavor is malty pungent peppery a bit astringent nutmeg cloves cinnamon sweet fruity. Finishes bitter sweet spicy and malty.

A-- Poured an opaque ruby color, no head at all, small layer of film. Just a few small carbonation bubbles.

S-- All spice, Nutmeg, pumpkin and rum. ABV is well hidden for a high ABV beer.

T-- Dark rum, all spice, nutmeg, and pumpkin. Very sweet and a lot of alcohol.

M-- This was tingly, thick and syrupy. Very sweet and a lot of alcohol. Was told Goslings rum barrels were used for it. Could easily taste that though. 

D-- Taster was more than enough. Great nose but after that not much great about it. More like rum and very sweet I thought. Too syrupy and not a huge fan of rum. Had to try it though.

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2012 just had this years rumpkin, best beer of all time. Its so good I think I quit drinking because I will never want to drink anything else. This years is 18.1% its a great red-brown color, the fresh (not canned) pumkin flavor is amazing you get a lil rum alc at first but finishes crazzy smooth for 18.1%.

Thanks to barzigkin for sharing this bottle.

The beer pours a hazy orange color with no real head. The aroma has a lot of pumpkin pie spices in it, as well as some rum notes. I get some cinnamon and allspice most predominantly. The flavor is similar. I get some big pumpkin notes, as well as some cinnamon, allspice and cloves. There is also a good dose of oak and a ton of rum character. The beer is very boozy and fairly sweet. Medium to thick mouthfeel and medium carbonation.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2013 Pours a flat looking hazy amber.  Very gorgeous creamy pumpkin spice aroma.  Interesting spicy pumpkin and herbal flavors followed by a slight alcohol burn in the back of the throat.  Overall, nice but too big to drink if you have to drive home (as I do).Thanks to BarZigKin for sharing.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2012 Bottle had almost 1 year on it. Great light ruby color, almost no head. Great balance of pumpkin, malt, and rum. Low to no hop flavor. This one might defeat pumpking as the best pumpkin beer out there.

Bottle: &nbsp Deep amber, a bit reddish, thick, a bit cloudy, large frothy sandy head, spotty lacing. &nbsp Nose tells me this is going to be a big beer, a big sweet beer. &nbsp Getting spices, nutmeg, cinnamon, tootsie roll, burnt marshmallow,  and rum on the nose. &nbsp Wow, much more vibrant on the tongue than the nose suggests, and much more potent too! &nbsp Loads of pumpkin like spices, with vanilla, rum, candied walnuts, red grapes, figs, dates, and more rum. &nbsp This one, while not overly alcoholic is very warming, and certainly packs a punch. &nbsp Backside has a lot of fig/date like character to it. &nbsp Up front its all Pumpkin, but the back its all spiced rum. &nbsp This is tasty, and must be taken in small doses. &nbsp If you take a big swig you are reminded of the huge spiciness, followed by the big sweet rum flavor on the backside. &nbsp I am really surprised by this one, the flavors really work well. &nbsp I hope this becomes a regular for Avery, one that is more widely produced. &nbsp Body and mouthfeel are full bodied. &nbsp This really is the cognac of the Pumpkin spiced beer world. &nbsp This one easily exceeded my expectations. &nbsp Thanks for the treat Austin!

Bottle shared by alexsdad06. Poured hazy dark brown color with an average to large frothy light brown head that lasted with good lacing. Moderate to heavy pumpkin, yeast and spice aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Medium to heavy complex pumpkin, rum wood and spice flavor with a medium to heavy sweet finish of moderate to long duration. Complex standout brew.

Courtesy of rayl101 
Bottle: The aroma consists of heavy ginger, nutmeg, pumpkin, and spice. Im not getting any rum. It pours a transparent amber with with a small beige head. The flavor starts with lots of brown sugar, toffee, and faint fruit. The finish has lots of ginger and light clove. Its medium medium bodied with mild carbonation. Overall, a sweet and sticky "Imperial" pumpkin, but Im not getting much rum.
bottle. pours dark yellow light orange. aroma of ginger and pumpkin. very heavy booze taste and loads of brown sugar

Sampled on tap at Brouwers Big Wood. Pours clear cherry red with a  small ring of head. Flavour of candied sugars, dark fruits, spices and honey. Flavour of rum, candied sugars, dark fruits and wood. Full bodied, sweet, heavy, very smooth, oily. REALLY nice. Perfect pumpkin beer for those not so hot on the idea of a pumpkin beer! By far my favourite pumpkin brewskie!
Bottle from Mane Liquor. Very sweet brew. A touch spicy with a load of vanilla and rum overriding everything. Not bad but too sweet for my liking

12oz bottle purchased locally here in Chicago... Pours a mostly transparent caramel toffee hued consistency, lighter than expected, and topped with a light beige ring around the collar... Aroma is rich and sweet with an emphasis in concentrated dark fruit and pumpkin to go alongside a boozy rum presence. The latter takes precedence with the sweet boozy dark fruit tones while the pumpkin takes a backseat. Brown sugar notes mesh well with the aforementioned... Flavors follow suit with more of the same with an emphasis on the big robust notes from the barrel. Pronounced dark fruit and rum notes throughout. Pumpkin in the backend but gets overwhelmed by the base beer. Body isnt as big as one would thin but the booziness more than makes up for that. A fair amount of heat surfaces from beginning to end. A bit brash and too abrasive overall.

A legitimately insane beer, loaded with spice and flavorful pumpkin but also sweet and rummy.  Surprisingly hides its alcohol well for the ABV, you know its a bit bigger but I wouldve guessed 10ish percent rather than 16.  Interesting, worth having.

Bottle thanks to Ari. Pours a hazy deep amber with a gray head that dissipates to edges. Aroma is full of spices and rum with backing bread and hints of pumpkin. Flavor has notes of sweet grain and pumpkin with a strong rum and spice.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2012 Merci Phil! Gros bouquet dépices, ceux du rhum combiné à ceux de la tarte à la citrouille. La chaleur de lalcool nest pas si présente en arôme mais en bouche cest un autre histoire. Je trouvais le rhum peu présent au départ mais plus javance et plus lequilibre se manifeste. Ça reste un liquide extremement sucré avec une tonne de saveur, faut être avisé.
had with Britt. looks lime apple cider. first sip gave some shivers. but it got way better as I sipped. lots of alcohol and spices. solid brew indeed.

Rich, the richest pumpkin I have had? I am overwhelmed by booze and rum, did I know and expect 16% abv? Medium brown, with cinnamon and nutmeg.  Smooth mouthfeel, a tad above average.  No lasting head. Spicy invigorating but yes high abv aroma. Damn I must eat to stay balanced after this amount of booze, but damn worth it.

Rumpkin. Rum and pumpkin. The idea sounds absurd, which is why Im so happy to try it. Several thanks to jl28r1 for a chance to try it. Poured into a snifter. Bottled Oct. 5th, 2011.

3.0 A: Transluscent darker amber color. Just one finger of fizzy off white head that fell in an instant. Ill cut Avery a break since this has a monster ABV.

4.0 S: Definitely unlike anything Ive ever smelled before. Pumpkin (as in the real stuff) is explosively present in this. The spices have apparently died down a bit, but theres theres hints of nutmeg and cinnamon. Only mildly boozy, which is impressive for the ABV. Caramel maltiness. Rum adds a nice underlayer of complexity 

4.5 T: I must say I like this quite a bit. Rum and pumpkin work together. Its as simple as that. Like the nose, pithy pumpkin is abundant. Spices are a bit more apparent with nutmeg and cinnamon again leading the charge. Plenty of caramel with a light toastiness. Booze is there, but this seems more like a 10% brew than a 15.9% one. Rum gives a sweet molasses.

4.5 M: Heavy body. Rich creaminess with a sticky molasses component. Very nice.

4.5 D: I like this beer a lot. I think pumpkin beers are a great thing, but sooo many breweries bitch out and make weak, tasteless base beers and throw pumpkin spices in. Avery gets all the credit in the world for bucking that trend.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 01-28-2012 01:43:55

Bottle 12fl.oz.[ Courtesy of Secret Winter Santa ]. Clear medium to dark orange amber colour with a average, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy malty, caramel, wood, alcohol - rum, oak - wood, pumpkin spices notes. Flavour is heavy sweet and moderate bitter with a long duration, pumpkin - cinnamon, rum - alcohol, oak. Body is medium to full, texture is oily, carbonation is soft, finish feel is moderate alcoholic. [20120211]

Bottle grabbed by a friend.  Poured into a Portsmouth tulip.  Deep caramel in color with a quarter fingers worth of off-white head.  It is slightly hazy in clarity, but still transparent.  Nose is rather unique, I get graham cracker, pumpkin spice, some booze, but also pick up some butter....hope it isnt diacetyl. Holy cow this is a big beer packed with flavor! Rum, coconut, nutmeg, cinnamon, caramel, and some booze are the predominent flavors.  The palate is full and syrupy, definitely a sipper.  It has a long finish with soft carbonation.  A welcome surprise!  Definitely a massive beer that requires some time to drink, but I will relish the depth of the flavor as I sit and watch Game of Thrones.

I dont remember my first sampling, that is how strong this one is at 15%! Kind of like a boozy pumpkin pie shot with a perfume-like lather, spices,and a medium body with dry palate. Probably a bit over the top but I love assertive butt kicking brews. a slow sipper.

On tap at Avery. Smells like Pumpkin pie... like fresh out of the oven, delicious, delicious pumpkin pie. Very sweet to the lips, sweet and hot. Not sure I could enjoy the entire bottle, a nightcap for sure.

bottle..big sweet spiced pumpkin with ample nutmeg, clove, and spiced rum in the nose...syrupy body lends its way to an overly sugary, thick, spiced viscous beer...way too sweet, over the top, and slightly unpalateable...blah

12oz bottle from thirdeye11, thanks man 
Appearance: Pours hazy brown/amber with a small beige head and spotty lacing 
Aroma: Woody, rum, spices, vanilla and pumpkin 
Taste: Toasted malts, vanilla, spices, brown sugar, pumpkin and woody 
Very nice. Very boozy but not hot, Im surprised that is it 16%. Smooth and tasty

$10 at Beverages 4 Less.  12oz bottle, bottled Oct 2011.  Clear orange brown with a small yellowish  head, fading to a thin ring.  Pumpkin spice up front in the nose, pumpkin and barrel notes follow withsome light meaty umami.  Flavor is boozy--16% boozy, and does not hide at all--and has rich sweet pumpkin and caramel sweetness, spicy clove and ginger pairing with the high alcohol pepper notes.  Actually pretty dry, bitterness at a 2. Low carbonation with a big syrupy body. Nothing about this beer stands out in a great way for me.  The reason this diabetic beast is rated highly is the same reason Black Tuesday is--I dont effing know why people rate diabetes (beers) so highly, as it costs tax payers too much frickin damn money. This isnt funny.  You should probably cut back on the drinking, anyway.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
Rumpkin is one of the best beers Ive had all year.  Hands down.  It impressed me with its complex, boozy as hell taste.  Now I usually bitch about balance in beer.  I might give a bad rating if a beer that Ive had isnt balanced enough.  But in some rare occasions a beer tastes so damn good I dont give a shit if its balanced.  This is the case here.  This brew is full of Rum character.  Its what youre going to get the most in the smell and taste.  It can be overpowering but in this beer it works perfectly.  Everything else in the beer is there.  Molasses. The spices, Nutmeg, Cinnamon, and Ginger.  They meld beautifully in the beer.  They sit in the background while the oak and Rum dance around them.  Yeah I know this review is getting deep. =)  The Pumpkins dont come through as much as you would think and are hard to find in the flavor.  But it doesnt matter.  Everything else just works so damn well.  This is just one of those sit down and sip beers.  A beer to enjoy throughout a whole movie or evening.

Now the flavor and aroma are fantastic like I said but I also loved the hell out of the mouthfeel.  Its a dead beer.  Really no head.  No lacing.  But its thick and heavy.  Rich.  Coats the entire mouth and just sits on the tongue.  Lovely.

Bottle: Poured a cloudy dark orangey color ale with a sizeable foamy head with OK retention and minimal lacing. Aroma of rums and cinnamon is quite intense with loads of sweet notes. Taste is a complex mix of cinnamon, light pumpkin and rums layered with a solid but extremely sweet malt backbone. Body is full with limited filtration and good carbonation. This is a complex one for sure though it was too sweet (a 12 ounces bottle can easily be shared) to drink repeatedly.

(12oz bottle phaleslu).  This was a beer Id been wanting to try badly and low and behold if Peter doesnt send this as a bonus.  Awesome!  Pours a hazy orange-red color with thin tan head.  Aroma is pumpkin, sauteed apple, spices, brown sugar, rum, vanilla.  Taste is sweet with a nice mix of pumpkin, vanilla and rum.  Full bodied with a sticky flavor.  A little bit of alcohol warmth, but ohhh so smooth.  I just realized this is almost 16% abv!  This tastes like its 8-9%.  Freaking awesome!

Bottle, after a few draft samples last month. Pours translucent ruby chestnut, topped with a thin off white head. Beautiful aroma; the barrel characteristics predominate, with plenty of rum and lots of wood, with notes of vanilla, spice, and pumpkin in the background. Brown sugar and spice hit the palate for an instant, and are quickly overcome by rum. Intense finish, with lots of alcohol and dark fruit. I love the aroma, but the flavor doesnt measure up.
Aromas of alcohol, spice and pumpkin. Pours brown with a small off white head. Pumpkin pie flavor with a touch of rum on the finish.  Overall a very interesting beer.

Bottle. Much thanks to Dmac for sharing. Pours out a nice brownish/copper color with a small whispy white head. Aroma is really nice, some sweet pumpkin spice, cinnamon rum cake and light alcohol. Taste is of sweet pumpkin spices, cinnamon, honey, dark spiced rum, and a very slight alcohol notes, that is nothing short of remarkable given the extremely high abv. Really tasty beer.
Clear amber, no head. Sweet sweet malt aroma and booziness. Brown sugar and rum. Tastes like spiced rum and sweet potatoes. Pumpkin pie in the aftertaste. Boozy. Delicious.

Bottle as shown. Pours a clody copper with small off white head leaving spotty lacing. The aroma is vanilla and caramel. Thin mouthfeel with a rich malt with caramel and light spice and cinnamon. Easy to drink, an impressive Pumpkin beer from Avery.

Bottle thanks to 17thfloor for sharing. Pours a ruby brown with a small tan frothy head. Aroma is complex, sweet and barrel woody with some notes of vegetal pumpkin and a very light spiciness and a candied fruit note. Flavor has many of the same complexities, very strong and rich sweet vanilla, caramel, light candy woodiness and still some nice pumpkin earthiness that isnt overwhelmed by spices. Finishes sweet and woody, surprisingly smooth and not overly cloying. Medium full body and a soft carbonation. I cant believe this is 16%, not sure it is, very little booziness, really nice beer though.

On tap at the common table.  Pours a deep Ruby amber with a thin tan head.  The aromas are pumpkin, cinnamon,candied sugar.  The mouthfeel is very sweet, dry and has a heavy body.  You really get punched with the alcohol in this thing!   This was little to sweet for my liking.   Cheers!

12oz bottle, Christmas gift.  Pours a murky brown with moderate-sized bubbly beige head.  Aroma is a complex mix of rum, oak, vanilla, caramel, allspice, and just a tiny hint of roasted pumpkin.  Flavors are a bit jumbled and not quite as crisply defined, but allspice and rum shine through atop a chewy caramel base with sharp peaks of vanilla.  Texture is a bit slick, leaning toward a medium-heavy mouthfeel.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma of Rum, pumpkin, vanilla, slight oak, and a hint of spices.  Poured deep orange in color with a small, loose, tan head that diminished but lasted throughout and became creamy and dense.  Cloudy.  Sparkling.  Full of tiny-sized, particles throughout.  Flavor is medium sweet.  Tastes of rum, vanilla, pumpkin, slight spices, slight oak, slight spice, and a hint of alcohol.  Medium body.  Slick, then dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Medium sweet, Rum, vanilla, pumpkin, slight spice finish is lightly dry.  15.9%ABV is slightly noticeable in the aroma, but otherwise very well hidden throughout.

$13 twelve ounce bottle from Capones, pricey little fucker. Poured an ugly muddy brown with lots of floaties and a minimum bubbly beige head. Aroma is great with notes of pumpkin, spice, barrel, sherry, vanilla, caramel and raisin.  Fuller bodied with average to slightly strong carbonation, medium heat but not overpowering considering the ridiculous ABV. Flavor of pumpkin, spice, vanilla, caramel, toffee, barrel and a touch of bread. This is a great beer.

Really interesting beer. Obviously quite boozy but still pretty smooth for the percentage. Pours a deep orange with a wonderful pumpkin pie aroma. The flavor is deep pumpkin and the rum definitely plays well with it. Sweet but not cloyingly so. Nice treat.

12oz bottle from ericandersnavy, thanks Eric! Pours a cloudy, amber, red-orange tinted body with a thin, fizzy, tan head that dissipates quickly and leaves a light lacing. Aroma is fairly sweet with brown sugar, molasses, and slightly sticky and toasted caramel. Lots of pumpkin, some rum and vanilla, wood, and a mix of cinnamon, ginger, and nutmeg behind the big malts. Gets more and more boozy as this warms. Flavor is really nice. Sweet up front with lots of pumpkin initially as well as plenty of molasses, brown sugar, and caramel. Gingerbread, wood, and rum come out a lot in the middle as well as a touch of toast. Spices come on nicely towards the end as this finishes with a slightly sticky sweetness, a distinct alcohol warmth, vanilla, spices, and lots of rum barrel. The spices and barrel really finish this nicely. The booze is clearly there, but not nearly as overpowering as the aroma. Its sweet, but fairly dry with really nice, lengthy aftertaste consisting of plenty of pumpkin, lots of spices, barrel, and a very pleasant sweetness. Medium-full, slightly sticky body with a soft, light carbonation. Overall, a really nice beer. The aroma wasnt anything special, but the flavor and the way this finished really did it for me. Sweet and very warming with lots of pumpkin, but well spiced with lots of barrel while finishing well attenuated. I thoroughly enjoyed this huge beer.
Pours cloudy amber with very little head. Aroma is booze, Rum, pumpkin, cinnamon and brown sugar. Flavor is pumpkin, Rum, cinnamon, toffee and nutmeg. Medium to full bodied with a nice boozy finish.

deep amber/brown with a thin cream head.  nose is pumpkin, spices, vanilla, wood, no sign of alcohol.  great on the palate, huge notes of rum, pumpkin, spices, wood, more spices (reminds me of spiced rum), and a warming finish.

12 oz. bottle.  Hazy colored caramel pour, opaque, some tints of orange.   Aroma of pumpkin, caramel, booze, mild spicing.  Some barrel notes.  Flavor is strong on the pumpkin and pumpkin pie flavors, lots of rum and vanilla, an apparent boozy component.  Lots of spice, lots of sweetness somewhat cut by the booze.  Honestly, had I not known it was a pumpkin beer I might not have classified it as such.  Its just a bit too sweet though.   Alcohol is insane on this, though.  Was drugs my dealer?

Breaking a long hiatus to rate this beer.  I dont rate anymore, mostly out of laziness, but every so often a beer inspires me to out thoughts into words.  The aroma had me envisioning rotten figs covered in vomit.  The taste is a perfect balance of tea, cough syrup, cardboard, and pure sugar.  This stuff is terrible.  I am so completely tired of these sugar bombs that are being passed off as beer.  Fuck this beer and all like it.  Give me something thats been through a fermentation process next time.   I cant hate this beer enough, and only wish I had more negative adjectives to puto into this rating.

12oz bottle.  Pour is decent, a nice red/orange hue.  Carbonation is light, but Im not expecting the best.  Nose is filled with sweet sugary aromas plus pumpkin, it does remind me of pumpkin pie, but also grandmas rum cake too.  Wow this beer is cloyingly sweet!  The rum aging hits hard in the finish, brown sugar sweetness, woody.  Its kind of one sided, but at the same time, exactly what I expected.  Solid if you want some sweet boozy love.

Kibble dominated nose. Its like huffing a bag of Alpo. It does have a sweet edge that I cant quite identify. There is also a creamed leather component. Appearance is murky brown, headless. Holy cane sugar, batman, this shit is freaking sweet. Cloying is an understatement.  Tastes still like kibble, but with heaping spoonfuls of sugar or hfcs Once the sugar rush subsides, there is a brown sugar, rum, and pumpkin finish.  Unfortunately, it is not enough to redeem such a horrid concoction.. Avery, particularly this beer, epitomizes my favorite line from Dead Poets Society., "Sucking the marrow out of life doesnt mean choking on the bone." Avery chokes continuously. The beer will get you drunk quick, but it is a cloying, nasty mess. Not even minimally enjoyable.

Pours a murky brown with ruby tones and a soft bit of off-white head.  Aroma is a fantastic malty-sweet-winey with wood and rum notes.  A fully loaded flavor; sweet and bold body; caramel, wood, rum, raisin and dry fruit with a smooth finish.  A fantastic, complex strong beer!

thanks Lee for opening up this up .. . pours a deep amber .. medium foam, light sticky lacing .. . lots of spice, pie, caramel, and sugary rum and brandy .. . even with the high abv, just a touch boozy .. . would be great by the fire while on fire .. . . please sit back and enjoy you chitty flight..

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2014 12 oz. bottle from Whole Foods-Brentwood. Pours a cloudy orange-hued amber with a small off-white head that quickly settles into a tiny ring. Big rum aroma, with notes of pumpkin, brown sugar, caramel, cinnamon, gingerbread- hot booze sits in the nostrils. Flavor of rum, toffee, pumpkin pie, oak, vegetal pumpkin, vanilla, nutmeg, and residual sugars. Medium-full bodied, with a boozy, sweet mouthfeel and moderate carbonation. This beer has balls. Re-Rate: Just too sweet. Good, interesting, but too sweet.

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2012 Draft.  Poured hazy copper with 1-finger off-white head.  Nose was brown sugar, heavy pumpkin spice and puree, oaky spirity notes.  Tastes somewhat sweet, very rich, complex, with a big pumpkin, brown sugary, and woddy vanilla bourbon working together nicely.  Delicious.

15-Feb-2012:  Re-rate from bottle, with the draft being looked at as the state more like the brewer wants the beer.  Pours turbid Carlina mud brown with 1-finger khaki head.  Nose is spirity bourbon and oak, vanilla, brown sugar, plum and pumpkin, plus some funk.   Tastes rich, dense and complex on the palate, with a big oaky bourbony and vanilla flavor, well integrated pumpkin, brown sugar, and earthy notes.  This one is bog and bold in either serving method.

Pale amber pour just a small ring of head aroma the glass ... aroma is of mostly rum with light pumpkin spices and caramel malts .... taste is sweet and spicy mostly rum pumpkin and spices are there but light mostly dominated with rum spices are balanced with none really sticking out malty backbone and a lingering warming spicy finish ... abv hidden pretty well considering its almost 16%

On tap at Brouwers Big Wood 2011. Pours a clear red. Smells like someone dumped a gallon of The Beast into a pumpkin. Banana laffy taffy, big time. Quite hot, although not 15% hot. Tons of artificial flavor... really just OK.

On tap at Rattle N Hum. Pour is clear copper with a aggressive white head. Aroma is huge! Pumpkin pie, brown sugar, rum, and caramel. Flavor is tad milder with a boozy/ wood barrel finish. Sticky and sweet with a good amount of spice.

Pours an amber color with a medium tan head.  Aroma has mild rum and some sweet maltiness.  Flavor is very sweet!...mild vanilla and spice...notable rum but cant find much pumpkin.  Mouthfeel is syrupy, thick, and sticky and the finish is sweet with vanilla and rum...warming.  drinks like a sweet barleywine.

Bottle shared by jckp64, thanks John!  Pour is cloudy brown with almost no head at all.  Aroma is sweet with notes of orange-flavored sugar, light molasses, and a touch of holiday spice.  Flavor is true to nose with sweet notes of orange, sugar and pumpkin spice.  Not bad.

12 oz bottle.  Pours amber with no head. Aroma has some spice but dominated with heavy alcohol. I was able to pick up some subtle fall spices in this beer, but the alcohol was so dominant it drown everything out. I was so excited to try this beer, but not worth the $12.00 a 12 oz bottle. It may mellow with age.

Oh shit, huge god damn rum nose, pumpkin spice underneath, a shit ton of residual sugars, spicy alcohol notes. Realy nice though. Pours dark amber, viscous looking beer, thin head, lots of legs, fucking eh this one is big. Flavors start with rum, move through concentrated pumpkin pie alcohol, brown sugars, caramel, alcohol, more rum, wood pumpkin puree and spices throughout. Huge body, lots of booze, but surprisingly well balanced. Good shit here.

Aroma of the pumpkin puree with some earthy sweetness is prevalent in the nose with the 5 spices. Pours almost ruby orange amber in the light with no head. There are muted sweet pumpkin flavors, light spices, and smooth notes of the rum that blend well together. Just a bit big overall for me even though there is no booziness.

12oz bottle, October 5, 2011. Dark copper with pretty much no head, whats left is a dark biege. Initial aroma is lots of fruit and mellow rum, some pumpkin pie spice but not overwhelming (maybe its the oak mellowing it out), vanilla. Below average carbonation but its nice, sweet but like the pumpkin its not overwhelming, little prickly but warming and smooth all the way through, cant get over how well hidden the alcohol is. Becomes a little dry, quite sweet but delicious. Favourite spice beer / pumpkin beer I have ever had for sure.

Brown color with a small, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of rum, caramel malts, pumpkin, spices, wood, vanilla, and alcohol.  Taste of caramel, nuts, rum, wood, vanilla, pumpkin, starch, spices, and alcohol in the finish.

On tap at Brouwers for Big Wood, pours a mostly clear pinkish red with a small ring of beige head. Aroma of a melange of spices (nutmeg, coriander, vanilla, etc.), pumpkin puree, and rum barrels - quite heaty but not boozy in a bad way. Flavour is quite sweet and liqueur-like, with sweet rum, pumpkin puree, some subtle spices (but pushed back further). ABV is totally hidden. A delicious extreme, unorthodox take on the style.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy auburn with orange hues.  Aroma of pumpkin, cinnamon, rum, wood and caramel.  Flavor is pumpkin, caramel, vanilla, cinnamon, rum, oak, alcohol.  I love rum and the melding of the pumpkin with the rum is outstanding.

Tap at Capones.  Pours a hazy deep brownish orange amber with a small bubbly off white head.  Aroma of rum, dark fruits, and pumpkin pie spices.  Flavor of pumpkin pie, vanilla, rum, sweet sugary notes and dark fruits.

On tap at Capones. Poured a deep orangish color with a small sized head. I would say Rum dominates... especially as it warms up. Pumpkin, spices, coconut and some wood in the back ground, but all about the Rum.

6 oz. pour from the Big Wood event at Brouwers. Very pungent. Boozy rum aroma, with some gourd (pumpkin), and cinnamon; those are the only pieces of the aroma that I can speak of. Transparent brown body, with no head to speak of. Flavor is intense rum and cinnamon, with a touch of pumpkin here and there. The rum cuts right to my taste buds. If there is ONE alcoholic beverage that I drink besides beers, its rum, and I can taste that shit every which way here. Even rating this ~30 minutes after tasting it, I still have that taste in my mouth. Slight wood touches here and there, as well. The rum dominates, the spices come second, and after that its a long drawn out alcoholic ride. Too much rum here; it interferes with the spices. Great beer, but I could have appreciate a little less presence of the rum. Too thin of a texture for the style.

6 ounce pour into a globe glass at Big Wood festival at Brouwers in Seattle. Pours clear ruby with about a finger of off-white head. 

Smells very strongly of sweet fruit, its kind of like rotting fruit. Not in a bad way, just the way it gets stronger and sweeter when it rots. You can smell the rum from a mile away. There are a few light spices and I can detect very little pumpkin.

The taste was a lot of booze and sweet fruits. No surprises. Very crisp and full. 

Palate was decent. Lots of alcohol bite and very carbonated. 

Overall, I expected more from this. Love the style, and love the brewery, but Great Pumpkin still stands as my favorite pumpkin beer.

On tap at Capones.  Cloudy brown with a thin beige head stained with tan spots.  Nose is earthy pumpkin, nutmeg, cinnamon and rum.  Medium body with a tang and some heat.  Taste is upfront rum, toffee, subtle spice and pumpkin.  A touch buttery, quite sticky.  I like rum, enjoyed this.

[355ml bottle courtesy of cgarvieuk] Dark, reddish amber pour, with a fluffy, carbonated white head. Big, sweet barrel aged aroma. Huge amount of marzipan rum on the nose. Sweet, syrupy pumpkin and marzipan flavour leading to a pretty sugary finish. To be expected at almost 16% I guess, but the sweetness coming out of the pumpkin puree combined with the enormous abv got too much after a while [03122011]

12 oz bottle from Ratman from the Avery release. Nose is lots of oak, moderate rum, with light pumpkin, and allspice notes. Clear rusty amber with a medium beige head. Flavor is rum, pumpkin, cloves, nutmeg, and woodiness. Excellent stuff; wish I had Don get me a few more.
Weak pumpkin and spice in the aroma but they are completely overwhelmed by the woody rum notes. Flavor adds a malty sweetness but still not much pumpkin or spice.

Bottle thanks to Seth. Amber colour with a lacy beige head. Lovely woody aroma with pumpkin, coconut, Black Seal rum, some sake type yeast and oats. Quite sweet with spiced pumpkin flavour, plenty of alcohol, a little coconut again and some vanilla, oak and biscuity malt to finish. Superb!

Bottle at home ... thanks to seth ... dark copper brown ... sweet pumkin and barley wine ... light vanilla nose ... huge sweetness ... much more barley wine than pumkin beer ... little pumpkin ... soft malt .. a light rum ... heavy alcohol... very nice though

Sampled at the St. Louis RB gathering.  It poured a hazy deep amber-orange color with a small off-white head. The aroma was of pumpkin, cinnamon, nutmeg, caramel and vanilla. The flavor was of pumpkin, caramel, clove, rum, ginger and nutmeg.  Awesome Pumpkin ale.

Sampled at the Saint Louis Ratebeer Gathering in a tulip glass. Thanks, I understand only two cases were delivered to the Saint Louis region! Poured a nice clear copper color with off-white foam and a little lace, alcoholic legs when swirled. What do you expect from 15.9%?! Aromas of pumpkin and rum, sort of a vegetal barleywine impression. Heavy malt sweetness, measured hops flavor, syrupy mouthfeel, hot but not harsh alcohol. Definitely unique, but less impressive than I expected.

12oz bottle.
Deep amber pour with a decent amount of off-white head.  Nose is pumpkin pie, nutmeg, vanilla, and booze - smells absolutely decadent.  Flavor of pumpkin, wood, and rum spice with a ton of alcohol burn.  Would be absolutely incredible if the ABV was less present but still a tasty and unique brew.

4oz pour at Churchkey is a hazy, ruby red with a thin, off white head.  Nose is nice, pumpkin pie spices, tropical fruit, jelly beans, coconut, pineapple, a little nutmeg.  Flavor is nice, agave nectar, pineapple, apple sauce, very sweet, honey, rum, cloves, carrots.  Full bodied, sweet finish.  A very nice balance of pumpkin and rum.

Tap at Churchkey. Pours a flat, clear, deep jewel ruby. No head formation. Nose is 100% strawberry Twizzlers with starchy sugar, thick artificial strawberry, and big candied yams so much so that they come across as straight sugary candy. Nose has overtones of cider vinegar. Odd stuff. Dont really get "pumpkin" or "rum." Then again, Goslings rum is pretty inferior stuff and the barrels probably have no character left. Taste is wildly sweet...its not bad in any way, but there is just no way to drink more than 4oz of this. If you have a bomber at home, you might want to call up some friends or share this at a Christmas party. Very sweet with strawberry candies, Twizzlers, cinnamon, perhaps something like candied yams but it is just too over the top. In fact, if this were given to me blind,  "pumpkin" is one of the last things I would ever guess. Thick, sugary, dessert palate gets a little mealy and actually chalky somehow. Not bad...but Ill stick with Meph Addict ;)

Dear god thats a lot of alcohol.  You need this to be very warm, and sip very slow.  So, you cant really drink it like beer.  But, once you get this down, its pretty tasty.

Basically it tastes like dark rum with pumpkin spice.  Nose is about the same as that.  Sip slow, and for god sakes share the bottle or youll be dead.

Location/Date:Bottle on November 30, 2011 split with Dave.
Appearance: Pours a dark copper.
Aroma:Aroma pumpkin, yam and rum, needs to be warm, not cold..
Taste:Taste is of pumpkin, rum, some yam, just really boozy.
Palate:Medium body, longer finish.
Summary: Aroma is really off to me, but taste is decent...but this thing is just way to boozy, even just splitting half with a friend.  It opens up better when warm, but still strong.

(12oz bottle) pours a clear amber color with not a lot of tan bubbles. Nose of pumpkin, rum, vanilla, nutmeg, fall spices, and alcohol. Rich and delicious! Taste of pumpkin, vanilla, rum, spices, and big alcohol presence. I actually think the alcohol took away from it just slightly. Full of flavor, and one of the better pumpkin beers Ive ever had though regardless of its flaws. Very cool beer!

Bottled Oct. 5, 2011. Drank 11/29/11. 12 oz bottle. 

AROMA: Barleywine, molasses, pumpkin, candied dates, rum soaked raisins, mild spice (nutmeg, faint cinnamon). Get faint hint of the ginger as well as oak (and dash of vanilla) after strong swirl. 

TASTE: Rum barrel forward, pumpkin, barleywine, molasses, candied dates. Can definitely taste the oak and vanilla notes from the barrel. 

Subtle earthiness mid palate (perhaps from the wood). Faint bitterness on finish. 

MOUTH FEEL: Syrupy. Fair amount of heat from alcohol. Feels like the aging in barrels smoothed it out a bit (ie, took some of the edge off).

OVERALL: Typical big beer from Avery: massive and somewhat cloying. However, I had this instead of dessert because I knew it would be quite sweet. So since I was wanting something sweet after dinner, I found this brew quite enjoyable.

12 oz. bottle from Grape & Gourmet.  Pours dark orange with a barely noticeable head.  Aroma of light pumpkin, rum, and cinnamon with an almost citrusy bouquet.  The flavor is more sweet than pumpkin and the rum really shines.  To think of this as a pumpkin ale is really unfair in comparison to other beers of this style.  While sweet, the taste is not cloying.  There is noticeable warmth from the alcohol but surprisingly it is not too strong.  A really good beer from Avery.
Big thick pumpkin taste, massive rum barrel notes that take this beer over. Tawny in color, almost no head, but expected with the barrel aging. Nice ginger in the nose, light cinnamon,

12 oz. bottle with Thanksgiving dessert.  Pours a dark brown with a virtually no head.  aroma is intense with a lot of rum, pumpkin, fall spices, wood, and some booze.  flavor is of rum, pumpkin, fall spices, burnt wood, and butter.  has a full body with a boozy, thick Mouthfeel., and a very warming finish.  overall, a vey good imperial pumpkin ale that went great with the pumpkin pie. I had for dessert.
From a bottle,dark orange,you can taste the rum.Interesting take on a pumpkin ale.Ill drink more of this.

12 oz bottle from Bevmo. Pours a translucent chestnut brown color with no head retention. The aroma is all sweet malts, caramel and toffee. The flavor is similar to the aroma; lots of toffee, caramel, malts, a touch of squash, mild spices and a fair amount of hot alcohol. The palate is slightly syrupy and the carbonation is soft. Finishes long and sweet. Overall: Way to sweet for my taste, and the high alcohol was a bit distracting.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2011 Bottle  Murky toasted caramel ale with a small, creamy, off-white head. Good retention. The bouquet is chock-full-o-wood and dark rum with a dash of nutmeg, a pinch of cinnamon and a hint of vanilla. Full-bodied with a skim-milk mouthfeel and stinging carbonation. The flavor offers loads of sweet dark rum. Not much gourd here, but there are gobs of caramel and a dash of pumpkin pie spices. Every bit as sweet and boozy as Black Tuesday. Luxuriant, uber-sweet finish with a big splash of high octane dark rum.

12oz bottle. Rating #84. Dark brown, burnt caramel color color with a minimal beige head. Aroma is similar to a pumpkin pie, except its more on the crust side than the spice side although the spice is still slightly evident and with a slight sour note that Im not sure if it should be there or not. Didnt notice a lot of rum notes in the aroma, it was there, but it was muted. Wow, intense flavor. Right off the bat I got a rum sweetness that was mixed with dark rich caramel and some spice notes that came in later with a subdued tone that melded pretty well. A little over the top, but thats what I expect from Avery. (2015)
user_location: Redlands, by way of Wisconsin,, California, USA

text: 12 oz bottle courtesy of adnielsen trade. Thanks, Aaron. Pours a darker amber brown hue, touches of red, fairly murky and dark with a decent carbonation, touch of tannish ringed head, dies to small clinger, tiny lacing. Aromas are a melange of buttery oak and rum, spice and pumpkin, caramel and toffee. Vanilla, cinnamon, nutmeg, and some clove. A bit sticky, more pumpkin comes into play. Not as luscious as expected. Initial is medium bodied, with a more potent flavor. Rum and oak mix with pumpkin, caramel, toffee. Biscuits and spices, pie spices with nutmeg, cinnamon, a touch of barrel and spirit heat, brown sugar and sweetness. Vanilla, more sweet sticky malts thinned a bit by the barrel. Man, as this gets further in its fairly hot and boozy on the palate, spices and pumpkin puree mix. Rich and spicy, a lot of barrel, but not overdone, just quite warm and spicy on the backend and finish. Flavors are solid, barrel is assertive, aroma doesnt move me. Nice. The barrels must have indeed been very fresh. Flavors are great, a bit hot.. A pretty nice beer with a bit of dialing in could be great.

Bottle. Muddy brown with a short, bubbly tan head. Strong pumpkin pie aroma with caramel, brown sugar and soft rum notes. Smells like dessert! Strong pumpkin pie notes, toasted malt, caramel, soft alcohol, spices, soft rum and sugary notes. Body is medium with a soft, creamy carbonation and a mild sugary stickiness. Soft boozy notes during the finish along with sweet malt, caramel, brown sugar, pumpkin pie with whipped cream, spices and light rum notes. Tasty!

Pours a cloudy tan-orange with a thin white head. Aroma is pumpkin, vanilla,  rum, bourbon, spice, some citrus, alcohol. Flavor is pretty interesting; rum, pumpkin, vanilla, some earthy/fruity/barleywine-like notes, strong alcohol kick; really sweet with a smooth but fiery finish. Mouth feel is thick with moderate carbonation. I would drink this all the time.

[bottle] shared by clear. Thanks! Pours a clear orange-tinged copper color with a soapy off-white ring. Aroma is light spice, nutmeg, apple crisp, brown sugar, pecan, some booze. Flavor is little pumpkin, pie spices, brown sugar, and some booze. Lightly sweet, with a little bitterness and herbal astringency.

Bottle thanks to CLevar!  Clear dark orange pour, very little carbonation and a good rummy and pumpkin aroma.  Flavor is smooth and slightly pumkin spiced and a nice syrupy sweet rum flavor which mellows and warms on the aftertaste.  Goslings was a perfect compliment to this beer, I cant beleive this is 16%!

Slightly hazy caramel brown pour,  with chunky lacing not much head.  Aroma of booze, caramel, slight spices.  TONS of brown sugar.  Aroma is burnt brown sugar, spice, rum, boozy. Slightly woody. Very nice.  Warming, dry.  Thanks Armin!

12oz bottle, courtesy of ablackshear. Thanks! Pours a clear, brown color with no real head to speak of. A little white ring around the edge. Aroma is sweet, boozy, rum, maybe a little pumpkin pie spice. Syrupy on the palate with light carbonation. Flavor is sweet, brown sugar, clove, nutmeg, alcohol, rum, vanilla, with a sweet, sugary finish. The alcohol is noticeable, but I dont know if its 16% noticeable. A very complex, very tasty beer.

Interesting beer here. The nose is rather odd. A bit sourish, leading me to think it was infecrted when actually I believe it was just the rum. Great looking beer with a very clear mahogany pour and a big thick foamy tan head. The flavor is huge with alot of raw pumpkin. Less spicy than many pumpkin beers. Kinda like barley= wine meets pumpkin beer. The mouthfeel on this sucker is huge and you do feel the abv but all in all I found it pretty well done. In fact I really ended up liking it more than most pumpkin beers because it was actually doing something different.

12 oz bottle.  Brownish orange pour with a short last head and no retention.  Nose is booze, pumpkin, pumpkin spices, and bready malts.  Taste was a lot of pumpkin and not as much pumpkin pie spices.  The rum has a nice warming burn and strangely enough I picked up some banana in the taste.  Overall a very sweet, boozy, pumpkin ale that will only get better with a little age.  Best pure pumpkin beer I have had to date.
12 ounce bottle.  Brownish goldish color.  Dog food aroma.  Hot and rummy.  Drinkable for how hot it is.

Been waiting for this one. Cant believe I found it in socal at bevmo. Aroma is subtle pumpkin but mostly sweet candy corn and rum with oak. Taste is super boozy but very flavorful in the finish. Dont get a lot of the pumpkin due to the booze but very enjoyable.

12oz bottle poured into snifter. As a pumpkin beer lover I was really looking forward to trying this and even though I gave it an OK score there wasnt much pumpkin flavor/aroma to speak of. The rum is just too overpowering and its just too boozy to enjoy. I might not be able to finish this bottle myself.

12oz bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a clear, copper with deep russet at the base with a thin, whispy, khaki head that leaves tight rings of lace around the edges. aroma is fantastic with beautiful notes of fresh, homemade pumpkin pie, cinnamon, clove, and spicy nutmeg backed by subtle notes of candied yams, orange peel, and ginger with smooth, spicy, and slightly woody notes of rum emerging as it warms. flavor is absolutely spectacular with huge notes of cinnamon, nutmeg, vanilla extract, and clove blended seamlessly with the subtly sweet flavors of my moms fresh baked pumpkin pie (complete with the perfectly toasted crust) and backed by notes of toffee, pecan sandies, spiked holiday cider, and rum balls. palate is medium bodied with smooth carbonation and a wonderful balance of pumpkin pie sweetness and spiced rum warmth. overall, absolutely the best pumpkin beer ive ever tasted.

Bottle from BevMo: Color was a medium brown hue that appeared similar to a glass of dark rum and had no head whatsoever. My nose picks up on a scent of sourness usually associated with a Belgian Flemish ale, though, some scents of pumpkin puree and other pumpkin spices come through in the aroma. Also, the aroma suggests a touch of sweet sugary syrup like malts while the rum barrel aging adds additional spices. As for the drink, the flavors are boasting of spiced rum along with the pumpkin spices. An intensely sweet flavor of candy sugars, molasses, maple syrup, and possibly a pinch of brown sugar. This beer is really held together by the barrel aging since the rum really rubbed off well and morphed this pumpkin beer into one that stands out compared to the rest. I just cant even imagine all the planning and work involved in this beernice job Avery. Well deserving a perfect score in taste.

Poured from 12 oz bottle.  Pours a deep copper color with just a bit of white head.  Aroma is tons of rum soaked pumpkin yumminess.  Taste is sweet pumpkin pie soaked in rum, with caramel, toffee and maybe some butterscotch.  Tasty stuff.  Really boozy.

Bottle.  Best pumpkin beer ever!  Pours a clear orangish-amber with a small beige head.  Aromas of pumpkin, rum, spices and oak.  Slightly sweet and syrupy but warming.  Rum flavors up front, followed by a great pumpkin/pumpkin pie taste.  Oak and more rum in the finish.  Alcohol is well hidden, just dont let it warm up too much.  Great beer.

Excited for this one! Aroma is figs, caramel, plums. Smells like a big malt monster. Minimal pumpkin, spice, or rum on the nose. Even a little dusty yeast. Pours a thick amber bordering on brown. Head fades almost instantly. Taste... dear God! Sweet caramel and rummy oak dominate the front end. The spice really hits in the middle and sticks with you. Definite cinnamon flavors and vanilla. The pumpkin flavors are there as well. The rum is apparent upfront but fades into the background. This really blends well together. The booze is well hidden but is present. Has some tawny port-like qualities, but with more spice and flavor. Very nice and very interesting. One of the few 10+$ beers I have been completely satisfied with. Get your hands on a bottle!

Sampled at an esbls tasting.  From Tyler.  Hazyvand dark brown.  An off white head head that fades quickly.  Pumpkin and spices in the aroma.  Huge sweetness here.  Pumpkin and brown sugar.  Spice and yeast.  The alcohol is very well hidden and is barely noticed.  This is really good.

Bottle.

Head is initially small, fizzy, light brown, fully diminishing.
Body is dark amber.

Aroma is moderately to heavily malty (caramel), lightly hoppy (apricot), with strong notes of alcohol and oxidation (sherry/cardboard/walnut shells), light notes of vanilla, candy sugar, and nutmeg.

Flavor is heavily to harshly sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter.
Finish is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter, papery.

Medium to full body, syrupy texture, fizzy carbonation, heavily alcoholic.

Fabulously awful.  On the surface this is sorta the trademark Avery beer...way over the top in alcohol and sugar.  But more than usual...and the only other major aromatic is oxidation.  So theres very little to like in the nose.  The tertiary notes just cant save it...theyre all but buried under the cardboard and caramel.  In the mouth, even worse...tooth-achingly syrupy-sweet with a savage alcohol burn and papery aftertaste...pretty much impossible to enjoy (or even drink at all).  All of this adds up to a likely Top 50 candidate on RateBeer, of course, but this is one of the worst beers ever made by this brewery.

Bottle courtesy of Scott - thanks!  Pours a dark brown/red with a slight, fizzy tan head that fades out quickly.  Aroma is rum, alcohol heat, dense and sweet malt, and some spices I cannot quite pin down.  The malt profile on the aroma reminds me of the Beast.  I do not get any pumpkin on the smell with the dominance of the rum.  Taste is huge thick, sweet malt (like a barley wine) with rum, spicy alcohol, and some spices.  I do not really get much pumpkin on the taste.  This is a huge, high alcohol rum-bomb of a beer.  Enjoyable in small doses.

Tasted on Halloween 2011 from a 16oz bottle, bottled on 10/5/11, thanks to Curtis.  Pours clear dark caramel with a thin beige head that leaves a thin collar of lace.  The nose is full of caramel, toffee, baked pumpkin pie, baking spices, and sweet rum.  The flavor is more pumpkin pie filling than anything else, with baking spices, sweet rum, vanilla, caramel, and a burnt toffee bitterness.  The body is full with just lighter than average carbonation and a long, caramel, pumpkin, and burnt toffee finish with the ridiculously high alcohol barely noticeable.
Brown pour, not much head.  Aroma is sweet, big,alcohol, pumpkin, spice.  Flavor is sweet and syrupy.  Some pumpkin, spice, lots of alcohol warmth.  Awesome.  Thanks aaron!

bottle courtesy of adneilson, thanks! wow. this is one HUGE pumpkin beer! the biggest ever i would say! wow! this is an intense and interesting beer. first off the bat, RUM!!! tons of rum, and in a good way. theres a delicious burnt sugar, molasses, prune, pumpkin thing going on here. this is a very hearty pumpkin brew, not light by any means. pours dark brown, looks, smells and tastes like a barleywine with pumpkin mixed with rum pretty much. it deliciously sweet and decadent, and is the only pumpkin barleywine i can think of. most people either do a lighter pale brew or a stout, interesting to see this take. great stuff, glad i got some to last for a while!

UPDATED: MAY 20, 2012 Rerate on 05/20/2012.  The aroma is like a barley wine, fruity, bready, also rum, pumpkin, brown sugar, vanilla, pumpkin spices like cinnamon.  Very nice.  The apearance is a deep amber/red, hazy, off-white/tan head, dissapears quickly.  The flavor is like the aroma, like a barley wine, with brown sugar, fruit, pumpkin, vanilla, booze.  Pumpkin takes a back seat to the sweetness, and rum.  Medium to medium/thick in body, creamy mouthfeel.  Boozy, sweet, pine hops on the finish.  Excellent.  The pumpkin was a bit overwhelmed here.  But I love this beer.

Draft at rattle with streets and Brendan.  Pours a hazy reddish amber with no head or lacing. Aroma is brandy barrel, cinnamon, aand other spices. Mouthfeel is medium with notes of nutmeg, cinnamon and brandy.

On tap @ RnH w Streets, James. Pour is rusty red-brown with tiny head. Aroma is a load of pumpkin spice and rum with a little bit of sugar/vinegar. Mouthfeel is heavy with some noticeable carbonation. Sticky. Palate is pumpkin, alcohol and some earthy malt. So different than any other pumpkin beer.

Pumpkin and sweet candy nose suggests a cloyingly sweet beer.  It is rich and definitely sweet, but quite pleasant, with a strong back of the tongue rum flavor and front of the tongue burn.  A very fun take on the pumpkin beer

2011 Elysian GPBF #2, listed at 16% abv. Clear copper color/ ivory head. Big rum spice, vanilla, wood, fall spice, caramel toffee aromas. Medium to full bodied with soft co2. Sweet spicy rum soaked pumpkin pie filling,  fall spice, wet wood, toffee, caramel flavors. Boozy warming finish--big ass pumpkin brew.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Draft at Churchkey. Pours a dark walnut with a vivacious head. The nose is absolutely massive; pumpkin and banana bread, gingerbread, candied almonds, vanilla wood, and that dark and stormy quality from the Goslings. The flavor is also insanely big; candied sugars, orange peel, pumpkin puree, fall spices, chocolate covered cherry, nuttiness, wood, and pineapple rum. Extremely sweet on the palate but not quite cloying, with the 15.9% ABV burning at the finish. Absolutely loved it; my favorite pumpkin beer.

Garnet orange poir with a rubust off white head. Aroma holdspumpkin and banana bread, gingersnaps,  caramel malt, and fruity booze. Uber huge flavor- a massive hoss! Super sweet and boozy with pumpkin pie meat, caramel, and pumpkin bread. Super thick and rich palate with a supple sweet finish. Low carb really worked on this one.

Pours dark reddish brown with nice fluffy and somehow lasting off white head.  12 oz bottle from the brewery, alcohol says 15.9%.  Nicely carbed, with aromas full of toffee, caramel, cinnamon, clove, slight ginger, big notes of brown sugar, molasses, some nice spiced rum, nice sweet pumpkin notes on there as well, really big and full.  Taste is just as good and the alcohol is pretty much completely hidden, starts with notes of sweet vanilla, brown sugar, toffee, and molasses, some nice cinnamon, clove, ginger, leading into a perfect blend of sweet pumpkin, rum, and a slight hint of warmth, balanced with a cinnamon, clove and ginger spice combo going into a nice dry, slightly bitter finish.  Carbed well enough to carry the taste through the palate, nice full on the palate as well to have a nice lasting finish.  Tasty stuff, best pumpkin beer so far.

Tap @ Elysians Great Pumpkin Beer Fest...  Poured dark, ruby-red with a khaki head.  Holy Mother this was an intensely boozy and sweet brew.  Borderline cloying but I enjoyed slipping it slowly.  Nose has some dark fruits and rum drenched oak.  Like I said, sweet and boozy, loads of alcohol (especially towards the end), but a nice mouthfeel. Malts and pumpkin spice too just take the edge off.

On tap at the Elysian Brewing Great Pumpkin Fest in Seattle, WA. Colour... amber-orange with no head at all. Nose... decidedly rummy with a baked squash and mild spice essence. Palate... starts off with a blast o booze (rum to be precise!) which continues throughout the drinking experience! After the boozy onslaught theres more of the baked squash aspect, but it is particularly pumpkin (rather than a general squash flavour) with a brown sugar glaze, a dash of pie spice and hints of oaky dryness. I must admit, most of the Great Pumpkin Fest offerings were down hill after this baby! Where can I find bottles of this gem??

Tap.  Pours hazy amber-tawny with a medium, fizzy off-white head, medium retention with good lacing.  Aroma is rum, spices, pumpkin, caramel and toast malt, nutty, and medium earthy hops.  Flavor is huge malt, sweet rum, brown sugar, low bitterness, pumpkin and spices with a sweet finish.  Full body, medium warmth and carbonation.

Nice orange brown with almost no head.  Earth oak notes (as opposed to wood tannins) and a datey fine rum.  Alcohol fumes.  Taste is all rum upfront but pumpkin kicks in a very even handed way on a long finish with some spice.  Very sweet just the good side of cloying.  Very good.

Draft at Avery, pours dull red with white head. Nose is loaded with fresh pumpkin, toasted pumpkin seeds, pumpkin rind, brown sugar, and toasted marshmallows, pretty yummy aroma. Flavors are very sweet caramel, toasted nuts, sweet booze, sweet pumpkin Flavors, charred rum barrel, toasted marshmallow. Long sweet booze finish. Syrupy body. Just too much for me but some good parts here.

On draught at Kraftwork for Avery day, what a rare find. This was one of the last highly regarded pumpkin beers I needed to try. Pour is a cloudy copper, with medium white head and awesome sheet of lacing. Aromas of nutmeg, soft pumpkin crust, slight cinnamon and vanilla.
